awd_titl_txt: Core Support for the Federal Demonstration Partnership
awd_abstract_narration:
The Federal Demonstration Partnership (FDP) is a cooperative initiative involving 10 federal agencies and 154 recipient institutions managing federally sponsored research funds.  The goal of the FDP is to increase research productivity by streamlining the administrative process for research while maintaining effective stewardship of and full accountability for federal funds. More specifically, FDP strives to maximize research performance per federal dollar by minimizing the monetary and time burdens associated with the administrative aspects of federally-sponsored research. Since its inception, the FDP has successfully worked to reduce administrative burden while accommodating continuous changes to the policies and regulations most significant to research administration. 

Through the unique forum provided by the FDP, federal agency officials work collaboratively with administrative, faculty, and technical representatives from a broad range of academic research institutions to identify and assess unnecessary burden resulting from policies and processes that can be addressed only through cooperation. Targeted projects, pilots, and demonstrations are an important and defining component of the FDP. Once a new approach is successfully beta tested by a few willing institutions and agencies within the FDP, it is generally accepted by the FDP's members and often by most research funding agencies and recipients. A study and 2016 report by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine on "Optimizing the Nation's Investment in Academic Research" cites and references the work of the FDP throughout.   The work that the FDP has accomplished in the past has achieved national recognition and the current proposal outlines further plans for maximizing federal investments in research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Federal Demonstration Partnership (FDP) is a cooperative initiative among 10 federal agencies and 217 institutional recipients of federal funds. Its goal is to increase research productivity by streamlining the administrative process for research while maintaining effective stewardship of and full accountability for federal funds. Through the interaction of its members, the organization is designed to:

  • Exchange thoughts, ideas, and feedback on current and proposed research administration policies and processes;
  • Reduce administrative burdens associated with federal research grants and contracts; 
  • Identify potential improvements and initiatives and demonstrate possible solutions.

On October 1, 2020, the FDP transitioned to Phase VII. Significant preparation preceded the transition to develop an updated Strategic Plan with a detailed set of five strategic goals designed to guide the work of the organization for the next six years. The plan is important as the FDP has experienced significant growth, moving from 154 member institutions in the last phase to 217 member institutions in Phase VII, 48 of which are classified as emerging research institutions.  [thefdp.org]

Committees composed of volunteers convene during the thrice annual general meetings; however, work continue outside the meetings. Projects and outcomes include:

The Expanded Clearinghouse is an FDP-authorized system that publishes online organizational profiles for use in lieu of subrecipient commitment forms. Pass-through entities utilize this publicly available information when issuing subawards or monitoring subrecipient organizations. The pilot was completed in early 2018. Today there are over 200 institutional profiles in the Clearinghouse, including from non-FDP member organizations and with invitations issued in 2021 to an additional set of institutions. There is ample evidence of the reductions in administrative burden and improved subrecipient monitoring attributed to its use. 

Faculty Administrator Collaboration Team (FACT): This initiative is focused on leveraging the unique opportunity provided by the FDP membership and meetings, where faculty and administrators attend together to enhance organizational faculty-administrator collaboration for successful research operations. Wide varieties of structures exist among FDP member organizations related to how faculty and administration interact on an operational and strategic basis. These structures exist for differing reasons and have varied degrees of success, from primarily historical structures that may no longer be optimal to more sophisticated and creative structures that take full advantage of the faculty and administration partnership. FACT has been exploring this vital research collaboration by collecting an inventory of as many challenges and successes as can be brought forward. After prioritizing key areas for discussion and analysis, FACT has proposed to the FDP membership a number of relation- and communication-based improvements.

A second phase of development and testing was completed on the IRB Exempt Wizard, a demonstration of an FDP-created tool that allows investigators to enter information about the human subjects protocol into an online decision support system in order to determine if their protocol needs to be reviewed by a full IRB committee or if it can be exempt from such review. Moving from a pilot to a full demonstration, the questions were updated based on initial findings and to conform to the updated Common Rule and then tested by the participating universities. Results were positive, showing with a high level of accuracy. 

Foreign Influence in Research is a topic of considerable interest to the FDP, with special update sessions with federal agency officials held at the annual meetings. An active working group shared information with federal representatives and will continue its consideration of such matters, providing collective input to the agencies as new regulations and/or policies are put in to place.

An Animal Care and Use subcommittee worked on the initial design of an online Compliance Unit Standard Procedure (CUSP) repository, where an index of substances and procedures that are commonly used for animal care protocols can be shared with the broader animal welfare compliance community. They also worked on a standard MOU for use in circumstances that involve partnerships between collaborating institutions involving animal activity. In April 2021, the NIH invited the FDP to translate the pilot product into an operational platform and launch the CUSP repository as a resource available to research institutions. 

The Data Stewardship subcommittee of the Research Compliance committee released the new Data Transfer and Use Agreement (DTUA) template. These template documents can be used to transfer de-identified human data and a Limited Data Set between universities and other research organizations. Having a standard template in place will save time in reviewing and negotiating DTUA agreements. A COVID-specific DTUA was also developed, further streamlining the agreement to enable rapid transfer of data between institutions.

One outcome of FDP's Strategic Planning Exercise was the creation of several new committees, including an Infrastructure Committee whose broad purpose is to identify, develop, and document tools for facilitating communications, information gathering, and alignment across all FDP operations. An Evaluation Committee was also established to create evaluation strategies to analyze the FDP's activities.
